dt: {bc}incapable of being corrected or amended: such as

quotes.t: Yes, this is a book about America … all seen through the fairy-book life of an {qword}incorrigible{/qword} kid, abandoned by his parents and brought up in a reformatory …

Eating fugu … is an exotic custom that probably would appeal to every {qword}incorrigible{/qword} mountain climber, skydiver and bungee-jumper in America. Why? The fugu is poisonous—and there's no antidote.

At the heart of Roosevelt's style in foreign affairs was a certain {qword}incorrigible{/qword} amateurism. His off-the-cuff improvisations, his airy tendency to throw out half-baked ideas, caused others to underrate his continuity of purpose …
The {qword}incorrigible{/qword} maleness of men is a standing rebuke to the Rousseau-inspired notions of human moral plasticity that are central to liberalism.

et: Middle English, from Late Latin {it}incorrigibilis{/it}, from Latin {it}in-{/it} + {it}corrigere{/it} to correct {ma}{mat|correct|}{/ma}
shortdef: incapable of being corrected or amended: such as
